In an attempt to work around defect 50347, I defined a project with linked 
source folders.  Simply put, I got nowhere.

Steps to reproduce:
  1. create a new project in the workspace
  2. add source folder
     a. create new folder, link to external source folder

During step 2.a, I get a dialog saying that the folder cannot be found, where 
the folder path corresponds to the linked resource path, only it's missing the 
drive specification (e.g. desired resource == x:\common\src, path reported not 
found == common\src).  After clicking out of the dialog, the source folder 
still shows up in the project folder selection dialog.  I select it to 
complete the source folder definition.

Once the project is defined, it's useless.  The source folders are displayed, 
but their contents are not loaded.  If I try to refresh the source/linked 
folder, I get the Refresh Problems dialog, with the following 
message, "Element not found: /common/src".  I looked at the folder properties 
(via right-click), and I see that it is defined as a linked folder, pointing 
to the correct location (I've confirmed this against the .project file as 
well).

While writing up the bug report, it occurred to me that perhaps the build spec 
system is assuming that folders are always relative to a single drive spec.  I 
repeated the above test case, this time using a source folder located on a 
location on my c: drive, and I had no problems.

I'm back to this bug, as I've encountered more broken behavior.

I just created an empty Java project in the following location (i.e. not in 
the default workspace) c:\dev\adv55\eclipse\testCommon

I then added a source folder linked to a linked external resource.  The source 
folder, was called commonSrc.  I defined the link using a linked resource 
variable, extending it in the dialog itself.  The variable is called "common", 
and it is linked to c:\dev\adv55\advcommon3x.  When I say that I extended the 
variable, I mean that in the new source folder dialog, when I select to link 
to an external resource, I am given the choice to extend a linked resource 
variable.  In this case, I extended it so that the full path is c:\dev\adv55
\advcommon3x.

Ok, now when I go back to my Java perspective, the source folder only contains 
the resources in c:\dev\adv55\advcommon3x\src, but none of the resources in 
its subdirectories (i.e. all the packages contained therein).
